title: Will a trilateral meeting take place between Chinese President Xi Jinping, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and South Korean President Park Geun-hye before 1 January 2016?
preds: It is New Year's Eve and a holiday in Asia, so a major political meeting will not be taking place this year, but maybe next year!

The trilateral meeting this question asks about basically took place on the first of november - so the cited reports for a potential meeting in the fall of 2015 were correct. This was a huge step forward in regard to their relations. However, since only Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea were at the meeting, while China was represented by Prime Minister Li Keqiang (and NOT the Chinese President Xi Jinping), this question remains unresolved. There are no plausible indicators for a second meeting in such a short period of time - and time is runnig out: 0%. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/02/world/asia/china-japan-and-south-korea-conduct-first-trilateral-meeting-in-3-years.html

Trilateral meetings involve cooperation between various countries, whereas bilateral meetings should be easier to organize. Trilateral meeting involve a go-between. Neither Japan nor China will act in this way through patriotic pride. It's very unlikely that Korea will do so.

http://thediplomat.com/2015/10/china-japan-hold-high-level-talks-prepare-for-trilateral-summit/ Taniguchi, a special advisor to the Japanese Cabinet, told The Diplomat that Yang’s trip is a positive sign. “Given how important Yang Jiechi is in the central apparatchik of the Chinese Communist Party, I think everything seems to be on schedule” for a trilateral summit in South Korea between Xi, Abe, and Korean President Park Geun-hye, Taniguchi said. “There is going to be an even greater chance for a bilateral between Xi and Abe to take place if the visit of Yang Jiechi is any indicator,” he added. "In their talks, both [Chinese State Councilor]Yang and [Japanese National Security Advisor Shotaro ] Yachi were full of positive words about the state of the relationship.  . . . Despite progress, both sides are still in ice-breaking mode and are far from real breakthroughs, according to Taniguchi. “Both governments are working very hard to project an image that they have made a substantial step forward in improving their relationship, but it’s all about appearance, not substance,” he said.
Events such as Yang’s visit result in announcements about the improving relationship, but in truth “it’s all about buying time and making a good appearance to the international community,” Taniguchi explained. “And everyone knows that. Underneath the surface, the situation has hardly changed.”
~~~~~~~

Think it will be Li Keqiang, not Xi. The intent of this question is unclear. Is it asking if a trilateral summit will take place? Or if those three people will be in attendance? China typically sends its premier to these things, not its president. I think that a summit will take place, but I'm unsure if President Xi will be there. President Park has publicly expressed her desire that he attend, and the two of them seem to have developed a rapport. So he does have reason to break with tradition and represent China himself.

First, there appears to be no reason for a meeting within such a short time frame.  If this were a routine meeting, it would be a very big event.  There would also be diplomatic preparations and these preparations would be public.  I can't find any. There are reasons for a meeting not to take place. 1) Japan's Prime Minister Abe's wife is the daughter of Nobusuke Kishi who was imprisoned for suspicion of Class A war crimes after WW2.  Memories of this are very long.
2) Abe has proposed expanding Japan's military role from home defence only to include combat roles overseas.  China has protested this.
3) Both Japan and China are in tough places economically.  Abe is promoting his "three arrows" (Abenomics) fiscal stimulus.  In as surprise move, the PBOC devalued the yuan in August.  It's not clear this is a "currency war" but neither side has suffered enough yet to come to the negotiating table. What could make me change my mind? 1) A regional emergency requiring such a trilateral meeting.
2) Public indications that such a meeting was going to take place.
There is too much tension between China and Japan to allow for a meeting.

Softening stances on the part of the 3 nations towards each other. Abe and Xi have met twice already. Abe's comment regarding the WWII comfort women may be enough for Park to move toward a trilateral meeting, and she is meeting with Xi in Beijing soon.

I'm moving towards the crowd, but not all the way because I think that if DPRK does a nuke test or launches a missile that could radically change things and Xi may decide to participate rather than Li.
Regional tensions,  Jinping is going to Washington, but he also sent an armada to the Aleutians
Belatedly joining others in Li > Xi.

Not going to happen. Presidnet Xi is now in Seattle. Headed to Washington, D.C., No talk of trilateral meeting. "The summit could take place between September and November in South Korea, the Nikkei said, and offer a stage for a first bilateral meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Park Geun-hye since taking office in 2012 and 2013 respectively."

With the recent push for a Japan that can project a military presence abroad, I see no reason that China will be friendly with them. I hear the drum beat of war...., not the lull of peace and cooperation.

If Japan's rep is the lowest ranking guy in the room, everybody's could save face.
China prefers to divide and conquer.
No, not as the question is stated. There will be a trilateral meeting before 2016, but China will send Prime Minister Li Keqiang instead of president Xi Jinping.
I'm lowering my forecast to be closer to the crowd.  I don't quite understand why crowd sentiment has changed so much; there don't seem to have been any major external events affecting this question.
This meeting will not take place by January 2016 there is too much focus on China and the ADIZ island build up strategy for ASEAN countries and Japan for a meeting to take place soon.

I have not found an article from China confirming whether Xi Jinping or Li Keqiang will attend (just from Japan) but there are good reasons for Xi to go. China is making efforts to strengthen its relationship with South Korea.  When Park Geun-hye attended China’s WWII parade, she was the only leader of a country allied with the United States to accept the invitation.  She got a front row seat next to Putin who was next to Xi.  Her prominent position was not by mistake.  The last trilateral summit occurred before Xi became president. In the past the Chinese president has not attended, but Xi may not feel bound by how past summits have been handled, especially when his attendance can make a statement to the United States and North Korea.  China’s relationship with the United States is more contentious now than it was in 2012.  Also, think of the effect on Kim Jong-un (who has yet to visit China) if Xi chooses to go to South Korea for the summit.  This question is one to watch and my forecast may turn out to be very wrong.  I just do not have the sense that a firm decision has been made for Li to go.
Not seeing any indications that this will happen soon.

China and South Korea have agreed to invite Abe to a meeting before year end.  China is tilting towards South Korea and away from North Korea.  This could be an indication that China has become uncomfortable with a nuclear-capable North Korea and maybe sees more commercial advantages to a parternship with the South, now that it's economy is down. Note: Japan and US have ongoing conflict with US over South China Sea ADIZ and physical expansion.  This gives Abe a reason to talk and a reason not to talk.  Abe is said to be receptive. [2] Regarding the issue of whether it is Premier Li Keqiang or President Xi Jinping: Diplomatic protocol would dictate that heads of state meet head of state [3].  It is hard to imagine a hierarchy-sensitive country like Japan accepting a visit of Abe to second-in-command.[4]  So if the meeting pans out I expect it to be at same protocol level. http://thediplomat.com/2015/09/china-japan-south-korea-to-hold-long-delayed-trilateral-summit/ Xi and Park agreed to hold a China-Japan-South Korea “trilateral summit in Korea at a mutually convenient date sometime at the end of October or the beginning of November.” The announcement corresponds with previous reports that the three countries would hold a trilateral summit before the end of 2015. While the announcement came after a bilateral meeting Park and Xi, Japan’s Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga suggested that Abe would be receptive. Japan “will continue communications with China and South Korea and work out a specific timing and venue. Japanese media also reported that the first official bilateral meeting between Abe and Park will take place on the sidelines of the trilateral summit. Such bilateral pairings are customary on the sidelines of the trilateral forum, and Suga said Abe “would be happy to receive an offer” for bilateral talks with South Korea. Kyodo News expects historical problems (including the Japan-South Korea friction over the “comfort women” issue) to be on the agenda in addition to more security-minded issues.   While media reports suggest that Xi will take part in the summit, all the previous iterations saw China represented by its prime minister (Wen Jiabao, at the time), not by its president. That implies that Li Keqiang, not Xi, would travel to Seoul for the summit — unless Beijing wants to give the dialogue mechanism an upgrade through Xi’s presence.
~~~~~~~

Therefore, I believe that we have a defacto announcement of a meeting before year-end, which is one of the things that would entirely change my mind on this proposition.  So just one day after my first prediction, I am totally reversing!  Oh well, when I get new facts...I make new conclusions.

No indication yet whether this meeting will be with leaders or just ministers laying groundwork, but worth a bump in my opinion.  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-02/china-s-korea-agree-to-summit-with-japan-by-november-yonhap China and South Korea agreed to hold a three-way summit with Japan in Seoul in late October or early November, Yonhap News said.
Chinese President Xi Jinping and South Korean President Park Geun Hye reached the agreement when they met for talks in Beijing on Wednesday, Yonhap News reported, citing unidentified Park aides. Her office in Seoul couldn’t immediately confirm the report.
Leaning towards no. No sign of great progress lately.

I'm really surprised to see all the pessimism for this IFP (or are we just calling them questions, now?) This was one of the questions that I was following during the 2015 season. It really seemed like there was a push to have a meeting, but Pres. Park wanted to wait until after PM Abe apologized or acknowledged something in Japan/Korea's history (I forget exactly what it was). That happened earlier this summer. Most things I've read in the last couple of days about the trilateral meeting seem to indicate that there's momentum for it to happen (by the end of the year):
1. http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/09/116_185987.html
2. http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_international/706688.html And in fact... just today, Pres. Xi and Pres. Park met and: 
"Presidents Park Geun-hye and Xi Jinping urged resumption of a long-stalled six-way talks to curb North Korea’s nuclear ambition as soon as possible, and agreed to hold a trilateral meeting with Japan “at a convenient time' in late October or early November." Source: http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150902001200

Abe has aggravated all his neighbors with his visits to Yasukuni & mealy-mouthed acknowledgement of Japan's WWII war crimes.  Unless Kim does something that requires a unified regional response, I don't see this happening in the next 3 months. HOWEVER, these meetings can be arranged on short notice when the parties will be attending some other leadership meeting--ASEA, UN, etc.  I need to check the conference schedule for the fall.
I think all three parties have an interest in meeting, four months is a tighter, but not unrealistic time horizon for this to be announced and occur.

Korea is pushing for it and Japan has always been willing as noted in GJDrew's good article link.  It is notable that we don't seem to have much regarding China's position in that article.  Chinese leadership is quite distracted for obvious reasons.  And maybe China does not want to get in the middle of the latest North / South Korean drama until that situation has cooled off a bit more.   But practically speaking, we only have four months left in the year and no formal announcement.  This should be a bit of a spectacle .  The planning,  announcements, and fanfare should naturally play out over several months.  Next year seems far more likely, assuming one or more of the three does not offend one or more of the others and throw the whole thing off for yet another year or more.

I agree with Darren's comment - 4 months in 2015, not a lot of time to coordinate a summit with these complicated parties. I'm under 50% at the moment but think there are compelling reasons this could happen.
Not likely to happen. Xi has his hands full with China's economy and his political stability to worry about that.
With only four months left in 2015, conditions don't seem to have improved the likelihood of such an event happening, which at an annualised rate of 30% seems to be a bit optimistic.
Good link by GJDrew .   As the Asia economic situation gets worse it might provide a positive reason to meet if it could head off a currency war.
Unlikely, these are very busy people ;)

Korea is looking for one.   http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-27/south-korea-s-park-eyes-china-japan-summit-after-kim-showdown But harder to schedule than you think.  Also, China might not want one now because of their stock market troubles.
